messages.content: I just checked and you're writting the same repo_id for UID 50 and UID 70. This will mean that automatically one of these gets balcklisted:

I checked the UIDs you sent on https://dash.dstrbtd.ai/benchmarks and your train.scores are highly negative which is the second reason why a UIDs incentive would be 0 for a while. I added the top perofrming UID in there as a comparison to how low your train scores are compared to them. This means that when the new Run started and the openskill competition was reset those UIDs perfromed poorly for several matches in a row. 

Since your scores are highly negative you'd have to run the miner with optimal performance for a few days to get back into the positives, alternatively you can register a new UID or wait until we start a new run next week.

Yes that's been the case since day one FYI: https://github.com/dstrbtd/DistributedTraining/blob/6e05c77dc3327935a68b7fcdde2fe4cfd81623db/distributed_training/utils/uids.py#L313-L326. This is to combat miners trying to run multiple miners with just the same model being uploaded.

messages.content: The master validator was looping trying to find 50 active UIDs but it seems there are only about 45 now so the min number of miners needed to allreduce has been reduced to circumvent this.

If they where terminated btw they will have had a valid_score = 0 and will have just been scored 0 without resorting to the openskill model. So the current scores are a good indication of the scores you had before you switched off. It's only when you're running a miner with low competitive scores that you get such negative figures.
less active miners is a bit concerning for the subnet, 😪

No that's not the case, check the code https://github.com/dstrbtd/DistributedTraining/blob/6e05c77dc3327935a68b7fcdde2fe4cfd81623db/distributed_training/base/validator.py#L381-L387. Any newly registered UIDs start with a open skill rating of 0. So long as you perform well in the competition with 24 other random miners your incentive should grow. Registration can also happen at any point in time after the Run. It doesn't have to be at the start.

Yes agreed, we weren't being low-key as a default strategy btw it was because we wanted to have some tangible results to broadcast first. Since we're on the way there with this current run we'll make sure to publicise results and plans on X more consistently.

Re Novelty, first we want to go through 1/2 more runs with more optimizations and hopefully better results before we schedule that in so that we have a nice stack of "novel" achievements to bring to the table.

Growing the team is a big aim as well but dependant on emissions. Currnetly our strategy is to offer bounties in return for some high impact delvierables that help us progress against the DT problem much faster whilst building up a pipeline of candidates to onboard once emissions grow.
Do you have an estimated time of arrival for everything to happen?
There's no single event that is going to happen. We are just going to focus on incrementally optimizing the current system whilst sharing our results / findings more widely.

was a trader that bought 5 days ago (155 T) and sold now
Ok his name was distributed training which is subnet 38's name so was a bit awkward
that is a name of a validator

The owner sells his alpha (very few, we're talking about 3-5 tao, sometimes less) at irregular intervals (every few days apart) and does so to repay expenses and development.
So I think you misunderstood what you saw in the transactions.

# SN38 – Distributed Training – Weekly Update
## 🚀 Run 7 Status
This week Run 7's great convergence continued. As loss started to naturally plateau at around 2.3 for the global model we're still seeing a continous improvement in results against 3 common LLM evaulation benchmarks (HellaSwag, PIQA and ARC-E).
## 💻 Validator Logs On Grafana
As we look to give miners better tools to enable them to understand the validator scoring mechanism better, we've now started streaming the master validator logs to Grafana: https://kmfoda.grafana.net/public-dashboards/042560a0b35d4c29a6f06136f827631d. Grafana's limits will probably prevent users from seeing more than 24 hours worth of data at a time but hopefuly this should be a good start. Later we'll look to add search options as well as longer time ranges if neeeded.

For now miners wishing to investigate their scores can:
1. Check their latest scores on: https://dash.dstrbtd.ai/benchmarks
2. Check the trend for each of their scores on: https://wandb.ai/kmfoda/distributed_training_validators/workspace?nw=nwuserkmfoda
3. Check how the validator is picking and evaulating their uids on: https://kmfoda.grafana.net/public-dashboards/042560a0b35d4c29a6f06136f827631d
## ⏩ Priorities for Next Week
Next week, we’ll be keeping a close eye on how we continue to perform on the aformentioned LLM evaluaiton benchamrks. We'll also continue experimenting with the findings of https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.23725. Preliminary tests on testnet have shown that these can speed up convergence by 1.12x. We'll now start testing the paper's claims around agressively compress pseudo gradients whilst still maintaining good convergence which will be a great stepping stone for increasing our global model size.

Have a great weekend all.

It's still the same run, Run 7. But it's constantly achieving a better loss and better lm eval scores.

Good question, based off our current loss and lm-eval scores we've achieved our goals for the 1.1B model. Our focus now is fully on increasing model size. Our dependencies for doing so aren't better results but some technical changes to the code base ( enabling model sharding per miner and aggresive gradient compression) as well an increase in emissions to enable miners to run more expensive VMs.
We'll be posting an update on how we're progressing against both these goals by the end of the week.

I'm not sure what the claim is here. If it is that we use SparseLoCo for aggregation and training convergence, that's incorrect. We use OpenDiLoco and have been using it since March 3rd this year: https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1281623984286334987/1346154060709101699. OpenDiloCo code: https://github.com/PrimeIntellect-ai/OpenDiloco/blob/2d750e58a692ce1424d2a2366b2b3de1f42c9bf1/open_diloco/hivemind_diloco.py#L61-L171 our averaging code: https://github.com/dstrbtd/DistributedTraining/blob/6e05c77dc3327935a68b7fcdde2fe4cfd81623db/distributed_training/averaging/averagers.py#L514-L622

messages.content: If the claim is that we're using Templar's Gauntlet / SparseLoCo for pseudo gradient validation then that's correct. We credit this here: https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1281623984286334987/1400412868712861785 and we also reference this at the top of the file that is referenced in that tweet.

**1) **Are you already "*using Templar's Gauntlet / SparseLoCo for pseudo gradient validation*"? Or not yet?

**2)** If you're already "*using Templar's Gauntlet / SparseLoCo for pseudo gradient validation*," did it contribute to achieving such a low LOSS in training the 1.1B model?

Thanks in advance, Karim.

The Gauntlet changes where focused solely on the incentive side of things, naturally that has some benifits in helping align miners to better reduce loss but it definetly wasn't the only contributing factor. I believe this can be proven by the fact that we implemented Gauntlet in `v1.1.8` but weren't able to converge and get these results until `v1.1.12`.

These are just some of the many changes that where made in between those two versions:
> - Using input tokens as labels since this is already done by default in HF's LlamaForCausalLM's forward loop
> - Reducing local_batch_size_train_effective from 2048 to 512
> - Increasing the outer optimiser learning rate to 1.0 to match the scaling laws of  https://arxiv.org/pdf/2503.09799
> - Removing hivemind's int8 pseudo gradient compression which we believe to be hindering convergence since it has no residual tracking / feedback
All of them will have had much more impact on our ability to converge.

@distributed・38 as Run 7 comes to a successful end we'll be merging the following changes: https://github.com/dstrbtd/DistributedTraining/pull/77 into main Friday, August 29, 2025 2:00:00 AM and starting a new Run 8.

This'll help us test some of https://arxiv.org/pdf/2505.23725 's main results out in the wild whilst we continue working on updating our codebase to enable us to grow our model size.
